results.title: Bossing
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “Plumbing”.
Instructional film demonstrating the skill of bossing - flowing or drifting of lead from one part of sheet to another by blows from hardwood instrument.

results.title: Copper flashings and weatherings
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Plumbing”.
Making a copper slate, laying out the job on a drawing board, cutting out, flanging and welding the two parts, annealing. Soakers, chimney apron, step flashings, gutter. Protection of corners, internal and external.

results.title: Walker
results.creator_credit: Alanis Obomsawin, Wolf Koenig, Penny Ritco and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Playing Fair”.
Walker is a young American Indian boy who has tragically lost his parents and is now fostered by another American Indian family. His only playmate and real companion is his dog. Jamie, a lonely young white boy has been made afraid, not only of dogs, but of people who are not white. Walker ignores the racist taunts and jeerings of the older boys who have influenced Jamie, and reaches out to him. Together they find friendship and understanding as Jamie learns to conquer his fears.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Alanis Obomsawin, Wolf Koenig, Penny Ritco and National Film Board of Canada

results.title: Mela's lunch
results.creator_credit: Sugith Varughese, Wolf Koenig, Penny Ritco and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Playing Fair”.
Mela has just immigrated from India to Canada and is trying to settle into a new environment. Finding new friends and getting used to new surroundings becomes difficult because Peter and his classmates are determined to make her feel unwelcome and out of place. They jeer at her because her lunch is different and initially Allison goes along with the group, but realises this is unfair. Her decision to stick by Mela and to get to know her better demonstrate that differences in skin colour and country of origin should not be an obstacle to friendship and self-esteem.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Sugith Varughese, Wolf Koenig, Penny Ritco and National Film Board of Canada

results.title: Hey, Kelly!
results.creator_credit: Sook-Yin Lee, Wolf Koenig, Penny Ritco and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Playing Fair”.
During a friendly game of tag, Robert calls Kelly a racist name and a fight ensues. Both Kelly and Robert are given detention, and the Principal gives them a task where they must co-operate in order to achieve the desired end. It is through this co-operation and working together, that Robert realises that he has a great deal in common with Kelly, and that her “difference” is only “skin-deep”.

results.title: Playing Fair
results.creator_credit: Wolf Koenig, Penny Ritco and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: A series of four dramas for 7-12 year olds intended to promote discussion on the issues of racism, respect and equality for children. Each episode revolves around a conflict where a child is taunted and discriminated against because they are a member of a minority group. The situations are credible and expose the impact of such behaviour on children.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Wolf Koenig, Penny Ritco and National Film Board of Canada

results.title: Carol's mirror
results.creator_credit: Selwyn Jacob, Wolf Koenig, Penny Ritco and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Playing Fair”.
Nobody wants to play Snow White in this year’s drama production except for Carol. Previous years she had to be content to play lesser roles or the wicked witch. However, for some of her classmates this is a problem, because Carol is not white. After much lively debate and creative thinking, Carol and her classmates find a solution and show that the problem is not Carol’s colour, but that the material itself and people’s expectations about Snow White are the real obstacle.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Selwyn Jacob, Wolf Koenig, Penny Ritco and National Film Board of Canada

results.title: Hudson
results.creator_credit: Robert Heazlewood, Tasmanian Television and Corporate Communications
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Player Profile Series”.
Football statistics reveal that there has never been a finer spearhead in the history of Australian Rules Football than Peter Hudson. Historical highlights and interviews provide an insight into the game’s most potent offensive player and prolific goal kicking machine.
